itemDescription: Welsh rugby union and rugby league footballer

wikipedia_page.main: George Rees (birth unknown – death unknown) was a Welsh rugby union and professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1910s and 1920s. He played club level rugby union (RU) for Ammanford RFC (captain), and Neath RFC, as a three-quarter, e.g. wing, or centre, and  representative level rugby league (RL) for Great Britain (non-Test Matches), and at club level for Leeds as a prop, i.e. number 8 or 10, during the era of contested scrums. George Rees was a bombardier during World War I.Rees was the younger brother of the rugby union footballers for Ammanford RFC; David Rees, Bill Rees and Tom Rees. Rees was the captain of the Ammanford RFC 1912–1914 "Invincibles", who did not concede a try for three seasons.Rees made his début for Leeds on Saturday 5 September 1914, he played right-prop, i.e. number 10, in Leeds' 2-35 defeat by Huddersfield in the Championship Final during the 1914–15 season. Rees was selected for Great Britain (RL) while at Leeds for the 1920 Great Britain Lions tour of Australia and New Zealand, although he did not play in any of the Test matches on this tour.

response: *George Rees (rugby), rugby union and rugby league footballer of the 1910s, and 1920s

link_mentions.page: Template talk:Great Britain squad – 1920 Australia & New Zealand Tourists
response: The photograph entitled Great Britain Rugby League Touring Team - Australasia 1924 does not show Ernest Jones (rugby league), and Bobby Lloyd but they did play in Test matches on this tour. Alf Wood (rugby) (), William Reid (rugby league) (position?), George Rees (rugby) (), are shown on the photograph, they didn't play in Test matches on this tour, but they may have played in tour matches, or had to withdraw from the tour after the photograph was taken. Joseph Doyle (rugby league) (), shown on the photograph, didn't play in Test matches on this tour, but he did play in tour matches on this tour.
